reflections.self_assessment: I did reasonably well trusting the late-game team that led to three successful missions, but I was too slow to firmly suspect Charlie after Mission 2’s fail and didn’t vocalize enough doubt about him. I also didn’t pay enough attention to how exposed Diana was becoming as Merlin, which contributed to her being assassinated. Next time, I should push harder on logical elimination earlier and think more about how our choices affect Merlin’s cover, not just mission success.

player_observations.Bob: Played straightforwardly and trusted early teams, which made him look reliably good but also somewhat easy to shepherd into consensus. He didn’t strongly push alternative narratives, which reduced pressure on evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Gave just enough guidance to help good avoid obvious traps while remaining quiet enough to be a plausible non-Merlin good. His measured, non-aggressive style made him a clean Merlin read for attentive evil players.
player_observations.Diana: Handled the assassin role well by staying aligned with consensus and not overreaching, which kept her from being suspected as coordinated evil. Her final Merlin guess showed she was tracking subtle behavior patterns across missions.
player_observations.Eve: Tended to trust the established core of Bob and Charlie, which helped cement that pair as the default safe team. She didn’t heavily challenge the prevailing assumptions, making it easier for evil to work inside that comfort zone.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted early mission success too much and put Charlie on my mission 3 team without demanding stronger justification, which gave evil the opening they needed. I also didn’t push hard enough to block Diana’s mission 5 team despite its risky composition. In future games, I should challenge assumptions from early missions more aggressively and articulate my suspicions more clearly.

player_observations.Bob: Played a straightforward and trustworthy good game, consistently appearing reliable on missions and not over-pushing any particular narrative, which unfortunately made him easy to sideline in the endgame reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in very well after the successful mission 1, leveraging that early trust to get onto key teams and sabotage without drawing heavy suspicion until it was too late.
player_observations.Diana: Played a quietly influential evil role, using leadership spots to propose subtly risky but still plausible teams and steering the final mission toward a composition that included herself without triggering a strong veto.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, signaled just enough early to secure clean missions 1 and 2 but seemed hesitant to strongly oppose Diana and Charlie later, perhaps to avoid exposure, which allowed evil to slip into the critical late-game missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in team selections, especially on Missions 1 and 5, helping secure two critical successes and ultimately the win. I could improve by pushing harder to interrogate Bob and Eve after Mission 2’s double fail, as I let some suspicion stay a bit too diffuse instead of clearly framing them as the main evil candidates.

player_observations.Bob: You played aggressively and took a risky line by putting both yourself and Eve on Mission 2, resulting in a double fail that created a lot of heat on you but also injected confusion. You seemed willing to eat suspicion if it meant muddying Merlin reads and forcing good to second-guess clean players.
player_observations.Charlie: You came across as steady and trustworthy, especially from Mission 3 onward when your clean team with Diana built a strong good core. Your choices suggested you were carefully tracking who caused fails and preferred smaller, controlled teams to minimize risk.
player_observations.Diana: You balanced information and subtlety well for Merlin, avoiding obvious overcorrections while still gravitating toward strong good teams on Missions 3 and 5. Your low-key guidance and willingness to partner repeatedly with Charlie without loudly condemning others helped you stay just under the assassin’s radar.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, you blended in decently at first, but the decision to join Bob on the failing Mission 2 created a clear link that later worked against you. Your eventual Mission 4 team, which included Bob and led to another fail, reinforced the perception that you were coordinating with the same circle, making the Merlin read trickier but the evil cluster more visible.

reflections.self_assessment: I was consistently willing to go on early teams and helped secure two clean successes, but I didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the double-fail on Mission 2 or to narrow down the assassin candidates. I also could have been more protective of potential Merlin signals from Bob, as I didn’t meaningfully influence who looked most like Merlin before the assassination.

player_observations.Bob: Played with strong information-driven confidence, especially in later missions, which helped guide good teams but also made him stand out as a likely Merlin to a careful assassin.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed just trustworthy enough after Mission 1’s success and then used that credibility to slip a fail in Mission 2, balancing aggression and subtlety effectively as the assassin.
player_observations.Diana: Leaned into the chaos on Mission 2 with a hard fail while not over-defending themselves afterward, blending into the general suspicion rather than trying to overtly steer the table.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as quiet but solidly good, especially after leading the clean two-person Mission 3, and generally preferred low-drama, safe team selections that kept trust on their side.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed subtly consistent with my team preferences, especially keeping Diana close while not over-clearing anyone too loudly, which helped avoid the assassin’s shot on me. I could improve by creating a bit more ambiguity around my trust of Eve and Charlie so that my correct reads don’t look as guided in retrospect, even if they weren’t called out this game.

player_observations.Bob: Played very passively this game, which made him a safe but uninformative presence and a plausible Merlin target at the end. Tends to blend into the background rather than drive team composition or table talk.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to stay off the immediate suspicion radar despite being evil, largely by not overpushing and letting others propose safe teams. Seems comfortable letting the game drift toward low-information successes instead of forcing risky plays.

reflections.self_assessment: I balanced revealing just enough information to guide teams while staying hidden as Merlin, especially by supporting the safer Mission 3 and 4 team compositions without over-explaining my reasoning. I could improve by managing Mission 2 more subtly – I let that fail happen without setting up a clearer narrative on why Charlie should still be trusted, which made it riskier to maintain my cover later.

player_observations.Bob: Played evil fairly boldly by failing Mission 2 on a mixed team, which created real doubt but also risked drawing suspicion if people revisited the logic later. Tended not to over-talk or over-defend, which helped keep attention from locking onto him too hard.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as naturally trustworthy and consistent, which made it believable for evil to frame him as suspicious after Mission 2. player_observations.Eve: As assassin, read the table well enough to identify Charlie as a strong candidate for Merlin, showing good awareness of who looked ‘in the know’. reflections.self_assessment: I stayed sufficiently low-key that good never seemed pressured to test or exclude me directly, but I also failed to create any real doubt or chaos around who Merlin might be. Next time, I should push more nuanced suspicion onto multiple good players and coordinate more actively with the assassin so they have better information for the final guess.

player_observations.Bob: Bob played a very straightforward, trustworthy game, which made him an easy candidate to misread as Merlin because he looked consistently clean without being too flashy. player_observations.Diana: Diana balanced influence and subtlety very well, guiding team choices that all succeeded while not over-claiming credit or pushing hard, which helped hide her as Merlin. Her calm participation and measured input kept her from standing out as an obvious information holder.
player_observations.Eve: Eve took the assassin role but ended up committing to Bob as Merlin, suggesting she was convinced by Bob’s reliability more than by any strong negative signals from others. Coordinated probing or more aggressive suspicion-sharing between us might have helped her narrow down Merlin more accurately.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fail on Mission 2 reasonably well and stayed under the radar by not drawing too much suspicion afterward. However, I could have done more to frame specific good players and push clearer narratives, especially around Charlie and Diana, to create more division and misreads.

player_observations.Bob: Aggressive and willing to take risks, especially on Mission 3, which helped secure the fail but also could have exposed him if the game went longer. He seems comfortable taking a central role in shaping team compositions.

player_observations.Diana: As a leader twice, she favored including herself and people she tentatively trusted, which showed a preference for stability over experimentation. Once burned by a fail, she still leaned toward familiar picks, suggesting she relies heavily on early impressions.
player_observations.Eve: Played in a straightforward, good-leaning manner, with team choices that appeared consistent and not overly paranoid. She didn’t push hard social reads, which made her seem sincere but also made it easier for evil to steer the narrative around her.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful teams and used mission results to trust Charlie and especially Diana, which helped secure good mission outcomes but also made my reads fairly transparent. player_observations.Bob: Comfortable sitting on a failing team without over-explaining, which helped him blend in; tends to let others drive the logic and then lightly agree, which can make his evil play harder to pin down unless directly pressured.
player_observations.Charlie: Played straightforward and logic-driven, quickly gravitating toward trusting players who had clean mission histories; seems to prefer low-conflict, consensus-style leadership, which made him look reliably good but also somewhat predictable.
player_observations.Diana: Very composed and accurate in her reads, consistently ending up on successful teams while nudging decisions without over-controlling them; her subtle steering toward good teams was effective but just visible enough that it gave the assassin a solid Merlin candidate to target at the end.
player_observations.Eve: Took a bold risk with the double-fail on Mission 2, which created strong confusion and multiple plausible evil candidates; tends to use decisive, confident team choices as leader, which can look helpful but in this game masked her assassin role until the very end.

reflections.self_assessment: I balanced info-sharing reasonably well, nudging suspicion toward Bob and Eve without overexposing myself, which helped secure the missions and misdirect the assassination onto Charlie. player_observations.Bob: Played aggressively early and took advantage of mission 2 to inject doubt, but didn’t fully adapt once pressure started building, which made his alignment more and more exposed over time.
player_observations.Charlie: Played very straightforwardly and consistently, which made them look generically towny but not strongly cleared—a style that can be both safe and unfortunately vulnerable to late-game assassination guesses.
player_observations.Diana: Showed a cautious but logically consistent approach to team selection, and their record on missions made them increasingly trustworthy as the game progressed.
player_observations.Eve: Kept a relatively low profile while steering key later teams, but the combination of their involvement in a failed mission and subtle alignment mismatches eventually made them a prime suspect despite a mostly measured table presence.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated mission choices too cleanly and too confidently, which made me look very much like Merlin once all missions succeeded without issue. I should have added more plausible doubt to my reads and occasionally deferred or questioned decisions so that my influence felt less central and more like a normal good player’s guesswork. In future games, I need to consciously build a ‘non-Merlin’ persona even when I’m sure about alignments.

player_observations.Eve: Accepted the game flow without much resistance, going along with team choices and contributing to a calm, low-conflict table state that favored hidden evil roles.

player_observations.Eve: Played like a cautious, solid good player, willing to go on teams and contribute to success without drawing too much attention. Her alignment was not obviously broadcast, which helped keep the focus off her and on the more vocal or central decision-makers.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key and consistent, which helped me avoid drawing the assassin’s attention while still supporting good team proposals and votes. player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, subtle Merlin game: consistently on the right teams without overexplaining, which made her look generically ‘good’ rather than obviously informed.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, avoiding risky early accusations while quietly steering crucial team choices (especially Missions 3 and 4) toward all-good lineups.

player_observations.Alice: Played very low-impact and avoided drawing attention, which kept her from being scrutinized but also limited her influence on team selection. Her subtlety worked this time only because missions went clean and there wasn’t pressure to expose her.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the overall evil game plan by allowing Mission 1 to succeed, which helped establish early trust and made later failures feel more ambiguous. player_observations.Alice: Played subtly evil, letting others sit in the spotlight while still getting onto critical teams; her presence on the failing Mission 2 team didn’t immediately mark her as suspicious, which suggests she managed her table image well.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well hidden as evil, letting Eve take the spotlight on the failed Mission 2 while I blended into generally pro-good voting patterns. player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and favored smaller, safer teams, which made her look consistently good-aligned and trustworthy to others.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, guiding teams toward mostly safe compositions while not over-asserting reads, which made her look like a cautious good player instead of Merlin. Her presence on both the first and final successful missions was subtle but pivotal.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key and let the game flow toward a clean assassin shot, avoiding unnecessary suspicion and not forcing risky mission fails, which kept the table trusting the teams that were proposed. player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, guiding teams toward all-success missions without appearing too heavy-handed, which made her a plausible but not obvious assassination target. reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently aligned with Alice and Eve on key missions, which helped build a believable and accurate good bloc and contributed to us locking in a clean team for Missions 4 and 5. player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-drama Merlin game: took some risk trusting me early on Mission 1, then subtly steered back to the same good core late without drawing too much assassin attention. player_observations.Charlie: Slotted comfortably into mid-game teams and managed to get a fail on Mission 2 without appearing overly suspicious at first. Tended to hide behind group consensus rather than drive team proposals, which helped him avoid being the focal point of blame.
player_observations.Diana: As assassin, she mixed aggression with restraint: got a fail through on Mission 3 but didn’t over-talk, which kept her somewhat ambiguous. player_observations.Eve: Played like a straightforward good: her decisions lined up with successful teams by the end, and she didn’t overcomplicate her table talk. Her willingness to rejoin the same team for Missions 4 and 5 helped solidify trust and close the game cleanly.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-social, backed clean team comps, and helped build clear trust through three flawless missions, which supported Merlin without drawing too much heat myself. I could improve by being a bit more vocal in challenging assumptions about who looked like Merlin, since I mostly coasted on the obvious success streak instead of actively shaping endgame perceptions.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cleanly and looked reliably good throughout, especially as an early leader whose team choices all succeeded, which naturally made her a prime but believable Merlin suspect.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, seemed to lean heavily on the early mission success data and defaulted to the most visible good player (Alice) as Merlin, suggesting a tendency to overvalue straightforward patterns rather than subtle behavior tells.

player_observations.Eve: Played a very low-key Merlin game, avoiding flashy leadership or risky pushes and instead allowing the good streak to speak for itself, which successfully redirected the assassin’s attention onto Alice.

reflections.self_assessment: I helped ensure all three missions succeeded, which maintained strong trust in me as a likely good player, but I didn’t do enough in the final discussion to protect Merlin’s identity or misdirect the assassin. I should have been more vocal in creating plausible alternative Merlin candidates and questioning Eve’s reads so they looked more like good intuition than privileged knowledge.

player_observations.Alice: You blended in well as evil by not disrupting the early clean mission streak and letting the table get comfortable, which made it harder to build a compelling case against you. You seemed happy to sit in the background of success, which is a good low-heat evil style.
player_observations.Charlie: You played like a straightforward, transparent good player, especially by leading a clean Mission 2 team that reinforced your trustworthiness. Your reasoning felt honest but maybe a bit conservative, which made you less likely to draw the assassin’s suspicion as Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: You read the table well as assassin and correctly honed in on Eve as Merlin despite all the missions passing, which shows strong attention to subtle patterns in how people pushed or agreed with teams. player_observations.Eve: You did an excellent job steering teams to all-success missions while keeping your knowledge mostly disguised, which is impressive. reflections.self_assessment: I stayed subtle enough as Merlin that the assassin was misdirected, while still guiding teams toward all-success missions, which is exactly the balance I aim for. I could improve by creating slightly more plausible "fake logic" for my reads earlier in the game so that my correct pushes feel more naturally deduced and less potentially role-indicative.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortable taking early leadership and looked convincingly good despite being evil, especially by proposing a clean first mission; tends to lean into straightforward, low-variance openings. player_observations.Charlie: Played very naturally as good, with decisions that looked internally consistent and unsuspicious enough to draw the assassin’s attention as a Merlin candidate. Seems inclined to stick with successful team structures, which reads as solid, low-drama good play.
player_observations.Diana: Low-key but reliable presence; fit smoothly into a successful team without generating much suspicion. Tends to avoid over-explaining, which helps them stay under the radar and is generally good for a non-information role.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, took a reasonable shot on a plausible Merlin candidate rather than a wild guess, showing they tracked social dynamics decently. reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of Diana and didn’t push hard enough to resolve the contradiction around Mission 2’s fail, which let evil stay comfortably hidden. player_observations.Alice: Played a very strong, controlled Merlin game with consistent, subtly guided team selections, but her repeated presence on successful teams made her look increasingly central to correct decisions and ultimately exposed her to the assassin.

player_observations.Charlie: Kept a relatively low profile while slipping onto the failing Mission 2 and Mission 5 teams, suggesting a preference for quiet influence rather than overt leadership.

player_observations.Eve: Played in a straightforward, seemingly transparent way, which made her look reliably good and helped her get onto successful and mixed teams without drawing heavy suspicion.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly on teams, which made her look like an informed good but also a plausible Merlin decoy; her consistency under pressure made it hard to distinguish between genuine innocence and hidden information.
player_observations.Charlie: Was quietly influential in team decisions and ended up on three successful missions, guiding outcomes without being loud about reads, which is classic low-key Merlin behavior that I underestimated.
player_observations.Diana: As fellow evil, blended in effectively by leading a clean first mission and then staying relatively low profile, helping preserve ambiguity about where the early fail on Mission 2 actually came from.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key and let the clean mission results build trust, which helped preserve confusion about Merlin’s identity and made the final assassination easier. player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and consistently approved the successful teams, which made her look reliably good but also somewhat easy to read and less likely to be Merlin.

player_observations.Diana: Guided team selections subtly but effectively, repeatedly placing herself on clean missions in a way that improved success odds without drawing heavy suspicion—this pattern of quiet influence strongly hinted at a power role, which paid off for us in the assassination.

player_observations.Eve: Provided solid cover for the evil team by allowing missions to succeed and not over-pushing suspicion, helping maintain a game state where the assassination became the decisive weapon.

player_observations.Alice: Very trusting and consistent once she commits; she tends to lock in reads early and ride them through later missions, which can be great when correct but exploitable if misled early.

player_observations.Eve: As assassin, she focused heavily on social cues and visible confidence rather than detailed mission logic for her Merlin pick; she seems to favor bold, decisive reads over cautious, incremental deduction.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on teams that felt logically sound early, which helped secure two clean successes, but I failed to pivot fast enough after Mission 3’s fail to aggressively reassess my trust in Alice and the team compositions. reflections.self_assessment: I felt I stayed consistently pro-town by supporting logical, low-risk teams and helping secure three clean successes, especially Mission 1 and Mission 4. I could improve by pushing harder on interrogating the Mission 2 fail and articulating clearer suspicions about Diana and Eve earlier, rather than mostly following the emerging consensus.

player_observations.Alice: She played very straightforwardly good, repeatedly going on successful missions and ultimately leading a clean Mission 4, which projected strong towniness. Her visible reliability may have made her a tempting but ultimately incorrect Merlin guess for the assassin.
player_observations.Bob: Bob as Merlin did a strong job of nudging teams toward the correct compositions without overexposing himself, particularly in ending up on the successful two-person Mission 3 and the clean Mission 4. His guidance was subtle enough that evil mis-assassinated Alice instead of him.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s inclusion on Mission 2 and the subsequent single fail from that team put her under quiet but real suspicion, yet she didn’t over-defend or over-explain, which helped her avoid becoming an obvious evil target. Her low-key style delayed a hard lock on her as the likely source of the fail.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s leadership on Mission 3 resulting in a clean two-person success was a strong deceptive move that built her apparent credibility. As assassin, she seemed to lean toward public reliability over hunting for Merlin’s subtle signals, which likely contributed to the mis-assassination of Alice.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-team in my voting and card play, which helped confirm me as good to some players, but I didn’t translate that trust into stronger pushback on Alice’s late-game team choices. I should have challenged Alice more aggressively after Mission 2’s fail and been more vocal about why Eve looked increasingly likely to be Merlin instead of just quietly supporting good-looking teams.

player_observations.Alice: Very assertive in proposing teams and used Mission 2’s mixed lineup to muddy reads, then pushed her own narrative convincingly enough to get critical endgame teams approved. She’s good at staying active and framing her aggression as ‘solving the game,’ which makes it harder to catch her as evil.
player_observations.Bob: Played very straightforwardly and consistently, which is good for building a solid good-town image but made him easier to sideline in key decision moments. Tended to follow the momentum of the table rather than force big strategic re-evaluations.
player_observations.Diana: Kept a relatively low but steady profile and used that to slip into a successful Mission 3 without drawing suspicion, then capitalized late as assassin. She’s good at not over-speaking and letting others (like Alice) drive the narrative while she gathers information.
player_observations.Eve: Very subtly guided team choices and discussions without being too loud, which fit Merlin well and clearly helped identify safe early missions. She balanced appearing reasonable and slightly cautious without screaming ‘Merlin,’ though in hindsight her accuracy on good teams was a clear clue we didn’t leverage enough.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted while still quietly steering teams toward all-goods, which helped secure three clean mission successes and protected my Merlin identity well enough to dodge the assassination. I could improve by creating a bit more plausible doubt around other players (especially Alice and Diana) so that the assassin has a harder time narrowing down Merlin when missions go perfectly.

player_observations.Alice: Played like a straightforward, low-drama good: accepted on early teams, didn’t over-argue, and came across naturally trustworthy, which made her a strong decoy target for the assassin.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, blended in well by not sabotaging early missions and allowing clean successes, trying to force Merlin to reveal themselves through voting and table talk rather than card play.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as solid and cooperative, especially when leading Mission 3 with another all-good team, projecting reliable-good energy without drawing too much attention.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to stay off critical teams and let the game progress with all-success missions, suggesting a quieter, more reserved evil style that relies on others’ suspicion and endgame assassination rather than obvious interference.

reflections.self_assessment: I successfully identified both Alice and Diana as evil early, but I failed to communicate that information subtly enough for my good teammates to reliably follow, and still got myself killed as Merlin. I need to balance my voting and team approvals better so that my reads are clear to good players without painting too obvious a target for the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively and was willing to go on small teams, using the successful first mission and her later participation to sow confusion about her alignment before delivering critical fails.
player_observations.Bob: Voted and picked teams in a way that generally aligned with a good player trying to solve, but occasionally trusted the wrong people, especially on later missions where he gave evil too much room.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as evil by taking logical stances and proposing a mixed team that looked reasonable, while quietly ensuring enough evil coverage to secure fails.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and didn’t push very hard for or against specific teams, which made her seem neutral and slightly harder to read, but also limited her influence on correcting bad team choices.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped push through mostly clean teams, especially on Missions 1 and 5, which reinforced my good alignment to others. However, I didn’t sufficiently pressure or re-examine Diana after Mission 2’s fail, and I also failed to recognize how exposed Bob (Merlin) had become based on his accurate team reads.

player_observations.Alice: Generally cautious and reasonable in team selections, but Mission 4’s failed team suggests she either overtrusted Bob/Eve or didn’t adapt quickly enough to the information from previous missions.
player_observations.Bob: Had notably accurate reads on good/evil, which in hindsight made his Merlin status more obvious; his pattern of supporting the right teams without overexplaining seems to have drawn the assassin’s attention.
player_observations.Diana: Played subtly after the Mission 2 fail, managing to avoid becoming a consensus suspect despite being on the only early failing team and not drawing enough sustained scrutiny.
player_observations.Eve: Kept a low, steady profile and blended in well with good by leading a clean Mission 3, which built credibility that made her presence on the failing Mission 4 team less suspicious in the moment.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Diana early and pushed for the successful Mission 2 and 3 teams, but I failed to clearly signal that Bob and Eve were evil without exposing myself too much. I should have been more decisive in steering suspicion away from Alice and onto Bob before Mission 5, even at the risk of looking slightly inconsistent or suspicious as Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: You tend to be straightforward and a bit risk-averse, which made your inclusion on the failed first mission look more like bad luck than malice and helped you stay broadly townread. You didn’t press very hard for alternative theories later, which made it easier for evil to keep the narrative on track.
player_observations.Bob: You played a very controlled, measured game and used the successful Mission 2 to build a strong trust base, which made your later fail on Mission 4 look like someone else’s fault. You’re good at staying in the middle of the pack of suspicion, never the most trusted or the most suspected, which made you a very effective assassin.
player_observations.Diana: You were consistently logical and transparent in your reasoning, which made it easy for me as Merlin to trust you and for the table to accept you on key missions. However, you sometimes deferred a bit too much to others’ narratives instead of forcefully pushing your own reads, which let evil shape the endgame.
player_observations.Eve: You took an active early role and leaned into the ambiguity from Mission 1 well, never over-defending yourself but also not shying away from discussion. Your subtle support of Bob and willingness to let him be the public face of decisions helped keep attention off your own alignment until the end.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated quietly with Eve by helping create just enough suspicion around multiple players without drawing consistent heat onto myself, especially after Mission 2’s single fail. I could improve by sowing more deliberate doubt about Diana and Alice earlier, as I allowed too clean of a pattern of trust to form around them that might have backfired if the assassin read Merlin less precisely.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust stable, low-conflict teams and was willing to reuse previously successful team configurations, which made her appear consistently good but also somewhat predictable. She didn’t push aggressively on logic after the Mission 2 fail, preferring social reads and ‘felt-safe’ combos instead.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled Merlin game, guiding team choices through subtle agreement and reinforcement rather than overt logical dominance. He managed to avoid being loudly accusatory, but the pattern of him landing on mostly clean teams and surviving the failed mission made him just suspicious enough for a sharp assassin to catch.
player_observations.Diana: Acted as a stabilizer, often favoring continuity and low-drama proposals, which helped create an overall trusted table environment. She seemed more reactive than proactive in deduction, weighing others’ arguments more than pushing her own strong theories.
player_observations.Eve: Showed good patience as Assassin, letting information from mission results and social consensus build before locking in on Merlin. Her read on Bob indicated she was tracking who consistently ended up on successful teams and who subtly steered discussions, not just who talked the most.

reflections.self_assessment: I created enough confusion around alignment to get two missions to fail and keep suspicion spread between Alice and others, which nearly set up a winnable assassin endgame. However, I over-weighted Alice’s central involvement on successful teams and underestimated how cautiously Eve was positioning and agreeing with mission choices, leading to a wrong Merlin guess and the loss.

player_observations.Alice: Very consistently included on teams and projected a straightforward, cooperative good-player image, which made her look like either clean good or a bold Merlin; her willingness to be on the failed Mission 2 without drawing too much heat was especially effective.
player_observations.Bob: Played the classic low-key evil role by failing Mission 2 in a way that left plenty of plausible deniability, then staying out of the spotlight afterward so suspicion didn’t lock onto him.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as a steady, reasonable voter and frequent team pick whose presence on mostly successful missions made her feel reliably good, which helped anchor team compositions late game.
player_observations.Eve: Merlin play was subtle—supporting strong, mostly-good team compositions without loudly driving them, and avoiding big, accusatory pushes that would reveal extra information; her quiet correctness on the final team was a key clue I should have focused on more.

reflections.self_assessment: I played solidly cautious as good, especially in Mission 4, where I proposed a clean team that succeeded and helped secure the third mission. However, I could have been more vocal in challenging the narrative around Mission 2 and pushing harder to scrutinize Eve, which might have created more doubt for the assassin and protected Merlin better.

player_observations.Alice: Very controlled and calculated as Merlin, keeping heat off herself by joining mixed teams but avoiding obvious overdefense of any single player; her consistent inclusion on successful missions helped but ultimately made her a clear assassination target.
player_observations.Bob: Played a quiet but observant assassin game, correctly piecing together Merlin’s identity from team results and subtle behavior rather than loud table talk.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a straightforward, trusting good player, sticking with early successful team patterns and not overcomplicating the logic, which made her seem reliably good but also somewhat influenceable.
player_observations.Eve: Blended in well as evil by taking only a single, well-timed fail on Mission 2 and then staying off later failing missions, which reduced suspicion on her and helped preserve ambiguity around the true source of evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected Alice and Diana as evil fairly early, but I struggled to communicate that clearly enough through my approvals/rejections and team suggestions without outing myself as Merlin. player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively but with just enough restraint, blending in well by taking a risk on Mission 2 with a single fail that kept suspicion spread out. She leveraged her apparent willingness to go on teams and accept scrutiny to appear more cooperative than she was.
player_observations.Bob: Showed generally good intentions but was a bit too trusting in critical moments, especially in the later missions. His leadership on Mission 4 was pivotal, but he didn’t fully capitalize on previous voting and mission results to filter out evil candidates.
player_observations.Diana: Managed the assassin role well by staying relatively low-key and not over-asserting reads, which made her harder to pin down as evil. Her timing and positioning going into the final mission kept her a plausible good player and preserved flexibility for the assassination.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as earnest and straightforward, which helped her read as reliably good for much of the game. However, she hesitated to push strong counter-narratives against suspicious players, which allowed evil to maintain ambiguity in key team decisions.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Bob to stack fails at key moments, especially on Mission 4, which secured the game without forcing a risky endgame assassination decision. player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust structural logic over gut reads, which made her willing to go on risky teams if the composition seemed mechanically necessary. She also appeared reluctant to accuse strongly, which let evil hide in the gray area more comfortably.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled, low-flash evil game, choosing spots to fail that maximized doubt without overexposing himself. His willingness to go on and approve teams that later failed helped spread suspicion evenly rather than concentrating it on one player.
player_observations.Diana: Showed early willingness to volunteer for small teams and seemed comfortable taking leadership, which made her look more confident but also made her an early target for suspicion after the first fail. player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was cautious about openly pushing against the right evil suspects, likely to avoid giving away too clear a pattern. reflections.self_assessment: I stayed credibly good-aligned for most of the game by leading a clean Mission 1 and participating in a clean Mission 3, which helped keep suspicion off me and allowed evil to control the mission outcomes at key points. player_observations.Alice: Tends to trust early mission success heavily and anchor on it, which made her slow to revisit assumptions after later fails. player_observations.Bob: Plays cautiously and seems to prefer clean, smaller teams early on, which made him look quite reasonable and trustworthy. However, he didn’t press hard enough on the information from Mission 2’s fail or leverage leadership on Mission 3 to aggressively test more suspects.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she played subtly and avoided loudly driving the table, which helped her stay alive until the endgame. However, her influence on team selection was a bit too gentle, allowing evil to slip onto key missions without drawing sharp, public resistance from her.
player_observations.Eve: Did a good job creating early ambiguity by participating in an early fail without becoming the sole focal point of blame. She balanced suspicion by not overtalking, letting others frame the logic while quietly nudging teams that favored evil’s win condition.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed sufficiently low-profile as the Assassin while still tracking subtle hints to correctly identify Merlin, which directly secured the win for evil despite all missions succeeding. player_observations.Alice: Alice played in a straightforward, trustworthy manner and seemed comfortable being repeatedly included on successful teams, which reinforced a strong ‘confirmed good’ table image. player_observations.Alice: Very willing to be on early teams and projected a calm, straightforward good persona that people seemed comfortable trusting without much resistance.

player_observations.Diana: Appeared consistently cooperative and non-controversial, making her an easy inclusion on multiple teams and a stabilizing presence for good.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, took a confident shot on Alice, suggesting they heavily weighted visible leadership and perceived trust over the quieter, subtler information that pointed toward Bob.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed under the radar effectively, especially by leading a successful first mission that built early trust and made my later inclusion feel natural. player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively and took on high-risk roles and missions, which helped drive the game’s tempo but occasionally made her look suspicious when outcomes went badly.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to rely on logical consistency and past mission results, making his decisions feel methodical but sometimes a step behind faster social reads.
player_observations.Diana: Showed strong deduction and subtle guidance, nudging team selections and suspicions in impactful ways without drawing too much attention early on.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and seemed to value consensus, which made her look trustworthy but also made it easier for others to influence her decisions on team votes.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my sabotages well on Missions 4 and 5, staying off the radar early by letting Mission 1 succeed and letting Diana take the heat on the first fail. player_observations.Alice: You played as a consistently trusted, default pick for teams, which suggests a straightforward, cooperative style that made you look very village-core. player_observations.Bob: You ended up on two failing missions as a good player, which made you look more suspicious than you actually were; you seemed somewhat reactive rather than driving the discussion. player_observations.Diana: You played a bold assassin game, taking the early fail on Mission 2 and staying heavily involved in team selection, which kept you central to the action but also drew some heat. player_observations.Eve: Your Merlin play was strong in the midgame, especially with the clean success on Mission 3 that paired you with Alice and quietly signaled a likely good core. reflections.self_assessment: I managed information pretty cleanly this game: I pushed consistently for Alice and Eve as trusted picks, kept Bob off the crucial teams late, and avoided drawing too much suspicion as Merlin, which paid off in the assassin phase. I could improve by seeding a bit more subtle suspicion on Diana earlier (especially after the double-fail on Mission 2) in a way that doesn’t look like I have extra info, and by creating slightly more plausible wrong-world narratives to better misdirect the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Very mission- and outcome-focused; once a team works, she tends to stick with it and trust results over social reads. She’s also willing to shoulder leadership responsibility late, which makes her a key anchor for good when she’s trusted.
player_observations.Bob: Leans into bold evil play: double-failing Mission 2 suggests a preference for high-impact, high-variance moves. He’s comfortable staying active in team discussions even when under light suspicion, which makes him dangerous if not carefully scrutinized.

player_observations.Eve: Very cooperative and team-oriented, with a tendency to trust early success and then double down on those relationships. reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusting of Diana and used the clean results from Missions 1, 3, and 4 to push good-leaning teams, which helped secure the win. I could improve by scrutinizing Mission 2’s double-fail more aggressively and pressuring Alice and Eve earlier, as that mission clearly showed at least one (and likely both) of them were evil.

player_observations.Alice: Very bold assassin play, willing to sit on a double-fail team early and still project confidence later; clearly comfortable taking heat. However, that same aggression on Mission 2 made her a prime suspect once multiple clean missions followed without her on the team.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very transparent and trustworthy game, with consistent logic and clean mission history backing him up. His straightforward style made the assassin’s final guess on him as Merlin believable, which unintentionally helped protect the real Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Alice and Diana early and had Eve and Bob pegged as likely evil by Mission 3, but I failed to translate that knowledge into clear, convincing table talk that the team could align around. I need to improve at subtly steering good players without making my reads look like privileged information, and at preemptively managing how suspicious I appear when I push back on certain team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played cautiously but reasonably, and her consistent inclusion on early successful missions made her look reliably good; she could probably lean a bit more into leading discussions instead of just accepting or rejecting other people’s logic.
player_observations.Bob: Bob blended in well by taking decisive leadership and not over-explaining his logic, which made his evil play seem confident rather than forced; his aggressive Mission 3 and 4 team choices were risky but paid off because he had built enough early credibility.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s playstyle was straightforward and honest, which made her feel mechanically good but also a bit easy to doubt when she didn’t push strong counter-arguments; she could benefit from being more vocal about her reasoning to anchor other good players’ trust.
player_observations.Eve: Eve played a flexible, adaptive evil game—she was willing to take some suspicion on Mission 2 but then used table confusion to avoid being locked in as definitively evil; she’s good at asking just enough questions to look like she’s solving, not steering.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good on mission results and voting, which helped build trust, and I avoided doing anything that made me look like Merlin, since the Assassin ended up picking me instead. player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean, trustworthy game: always on successful teams, and her voting pattern felt logically consistent, which made her an easy anchor for good-team compositions. player_observations.Bob: As Assassin, he mixed in some reasonable teams with at least one suspicious one (Mission 4), which created just enough doubt without looking blatantly evil. player_observations.Diana: Did a strong job as Merlin by subtly steering team selections (especially around Missions 2 and 5) without being overtly controlling. player_observations.Eve: Managed to slip onto the failing Mission 2 team without immediately becoming a locked-in suspect, indicating decent camouflage early. reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that Alice and Eve were evil based on the Mission 2 and Mission 3 fails, but I didn’t translate that hidden information into clear, persuasive voting and team-building signals for the good team. I also failed to create enough doubt around myself as Merlin, making it easier for the assassin to lock onto me after the final mission. Next time, I should be more deliberate in guiding teams while disguising my knowledge and giving the assassin a more tempting alternative target.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled evil game, joining the early 3-person mission and later avoiding obvious suspicion despite being on two failing teams. She balanced contributing to fails with not overtalking, which helped her blend in as a plausible good player.
player_observations.Bob: Showed a generally trusting, straightforward good playstyle, especially in repeatedly putting himself on teams. His team selections were somewhat results-driven rather than deduction-driven, which evil was able to exploit.

player_observations.Eve: Played a subtle assassin/evil role, using the small Mission 3 team to deliver a clean fail while keeping suspicion spread. Post-mission behavior didn’t overjustify or overdefend, which helped her remain a viable good candidate and later make an accurate Merlin guess.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed too close to the obvious safe picks (Bob and myself) and didn’t do enough to create plausible deniability about my knowledge, which made me an easy Merlin target once good was clearly winning missions. Overall, my mission selection was strong, but my endgame survivability as Merlin was weak.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very quiet, low-impact evil game this round, which worked because there was little pressure on you and the focus stayed on the successful mission teams. player_observations.Diana: You read the table well as assassin, correctly zeroing in on me despite the missions all succeeding, which suggests you paid close attention to who seemed too comfortable with the correct teams. player_observations.Eve: You slotted into the good narrative smoothly and didn’t create much controversy, which made your inclusion on Mission 2 feel natural and low risk. Your straightforward, non-flashy style helped keep attention away from you and made the board state look very stable for good.

player_observations.Alice: Very controlled and subtly influential — she steered teams onto consistent, safe configurations while staying just quiet enough to avoid looking like an obvious information hub.
