player_observations.Bob: Flew under the radar this game, with low impact on team selection and very little overt suspicion thrown around. That quiet, middle-of-the-pack presence made him a plausible Merlin decoy when we were desperate for an alternative target.
player_observations.Diana: Played straightforward, trust-building good — repeatedly pairing with Alice and supporting the same core of players, signaling high confidence in her reads. Her consistency helped make those small teams look legitimate and contributed to the clean mission streak.
player_observations.Eve: Took a conservative evil line by keeping Mission 2 clean, preserving cover but sacrificing late-game leverage and chaos. In the assassination, she seemed to lean heavily on table talk and the quietness of Bob instead of systematically eliminating Merlin candidates, which made the final shot more of a guess than a deduction.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently village-leaning in tone and choices, especially by supporting the successful Mission 1 and Mission 4 teams, which helped maintain trust on the good side. I could improve by pushing harder on structured reasoning after the failed Mission 2 to more explicitly frame suspicion on Bob instead of staying relatively quiet and just going along with safer team comps.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game: willing to sit on suspicion after the failed Mission 2 while still subtly steering teams toward safe configurations, especially on Missions 3 and 4. Managed info leakage well—enough to win missions and still draw the assassin shot onto me instead of herself.
player_observations.Bob: Took a fairly active role in team formation on Mission 2, which fit a confident table-presence style but ultimately outed him when that mission failed. Seemed comfortable staying in the mix after the fail, relying on ambiguity and shared blame rather than going low-profile.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally trustworthy and straightforward, which made her an easy inclusion on multiple successful teams. Her willingness to take a small, tight team on Mission 3 signaled confidence and helped lock in a clean success for good.
player_observations.Eve: Started strong by leading a clean Mission 1, which was a clever way to build early-towncred as assassin. In the endgame, her assassination choice on me showed she was reading surface-level trust patterns accurately but miscalibrated how much Alice was deliberately underplaying her influence.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently village-leaning by backing simple, low-risk teams early and not over-pushing any narratives, which helped build trust without drawing assassin heat. I could improve by being more vocal in theorizing about possible evil pairs mid-game so that, even in an all-success game, my thought process is clearer and more obviously good-aligned.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed relatively under the radar this game, which worked well in an all-success scenario but offered very little alignment-indicative behavior to read from. Felt more reactive than proactive, which can be effective evil play but also risks being forgotten in key discussions.
player_observations.Bob: Played in a very straightforward and transparent way, which strongly reinforced the perception of being generically good and safe to include on early teams. Willingness to repeat successful team compositions added to a stable, low-chaos atmosphere that benefited good.
player_observations.Diana: Balanced subtle guidance with restraint, nudging team choices and accepting low-conflict lines without over-explaining, which was very Merlin-like in hindsight but not obvious in the moment. Her willingness to sit on a small, clean team for Mission 3 was both efficient and low-information for evil.
player_observations.Eve: Took a low-commitment approach to sabotaging the social dynamic, allowing all success missions to pass and instead banking on the assassination, which is a reasonable adaptation when team control is slipping. The final Merlin guess on Bob shows she read the table as rewarding straightforward play with suspicion, but underestimated how quietly Diana was steering things.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that Alice and Bob were evil based on the pattern of fails, but I didn’t communicate my reads subtly enough to steer teams without exposing myself clearly or causing confusion. Next time, I should more actively shape team compositions earlier and use more nuanced, indirect resistance to bad teams so my information has impact without making it obvious who Merlin is.

player_observations.Alice: Played a quiet but pivotal evil game, choosing her mission fails carefully so as not to overexpose herself while letting suspicion distribute onto multiple players.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, he positioned himself well by staying reasonably trustworthy early and using the mission 3 fail to cast doubt on good players, then capitalized well in the endgame.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently tried to build logical teams and seemed genuinely torn by conflicting information, which made her look very authentically good even when her teams were manipulated.
player_observations.Eve: Played in a straightforward and transparent way, often trusting mission results heavily, which made her seem quite good but also a bit easier for evil to influence via mission outcomes.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped secure three successful missions, which supported overall trust in me as good. However, I should have pushed much harder on the implications of Mission 2 having two fails (clearing myself and forcing suspicion onto Bob and Eve), and I could have been more deliberate in protecting Merlin by sowing doubt about Diana late game.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cleanly on missions and looked solidly good; her successful leadership on Missions 1 and 3 helped anchor the good team’s trust, but she didn’t aggressively drive the deduction after the double-fail on Mission 2.
player_observations.Bob: Comfortable sitting in the middle of suspicion after Mission 2, likely relying on shared blame and ambiguity to avoid being cleanly outed as evil once the two-fail result came in.
player_observations.Diana: Took strong, accurate mission decisions as Merlin and kept the mission track mostly on course, but her pattern of consistently being on successful, safe teams likely made her look too informed and led to the successful assassination.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to coordinate or allow a bold double-fail on Mission 2 without getting immediately forced out, and then read the table well enough in the endgame to correctly pick Diana as Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I helped keep suspicion spread out by being willing to go on multiple critical teams, even after a fail, which made it harder for evil to lock onto Merlin and let good still form successful missions later. However, I could have been more assertive in publicly questioning Bob and Eve after the failed missions instead of staying relatively neutral, which might have accelerated consensus on a more reliable core team.

player_observations.Alice: Played subtly but consistently pro-good, managing to get on multiple key teams without drawing lethal suspicion, especially after leading the final successful mission; her calm participation style fit Merlin well and clearly misdirected the assassin. She seemed to balance giving guidance with not over-pushing her reads, which helped her survive the assassination.
player_observations.Bob: Was positioned suspiciously after Mission 2’s fail on a three-player team, but managed not to become the sole scapegoat, suggesting a careful, low-key evil style. He avoided loud leadership and instead blended into the middle of the pack, which let him survive socially even as evidence mounted.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as a trusted anchor after appearing on two clean missions (1 and 3), which helped form a credible good core later in the game. She seemed comfortable taking responsibility as leader and as a frequent team member, and her consistency made it easier for good to lock in a safe final team.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, she played cautiously enough that she wasn’t immediately written off as evil even after leading a failed Mission 4, indicating a willingness to take a risky leadership role while still trying to appear reasonable. Her final assassination on me instead of Alice showed she bought into the narrative that I might be Merlin, so she was somewhat successfully misdirected by good’s table dynamics.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed quiet enough to avoid suspicion while paying close attention to who seemed to have extra information, which helped me correctly identify Merlin as Alice despite all missions succeeding. I could improve by creating a bit more subtle ‘good’ table talk to misdirect post-game Merlin guesses further, in case my read isn’t as clear next time.

player_observations.Alice: Very controlled and confident in team choices, which fit perfectly with a cautious Merlin trying not to be too obvious, especially by repeatedly including Diana and avoiding risky changes.
player_observations.Bob: Played a low-profile evil game, staying out of mission teams and letting others drive decisions, which helped keep overall suspicion away from the evil side.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as sincerely good and fairly trusting, accepting the early team structures and not over-analyzing results, which made her a natural repeated pick for missions.
player_observations.Eve: Flew under the radar and accepted being added on Mission 2 without pushing hard for or against specific team comps, contributing to a smooth, low-conflict atmosphere that benefited Merlin’s comfort but also made her less likely to be Merlin in my eyes.

reflections.self_assessment: I helped secure an early fail on Mission 2 and maintained enough ambiguity to avoid immediate suspicion, but I didn’t coordinate tightly enough with Diana to shape a more convincing narrative about who was evil. I also misread Alice’s subtle guidance versus Bob’s more straightforward behavior, which contributed to the wrong assassination target and ultimately cost us the game.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, nudging teams away from danger without over-defending any specific player, which kept her off the assassination radar.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as straightforward and consistent, voting and speaking in a way that made him look like a typical, uninformed good player rather than a power role.
player_observations.Diana: Took good risks by putting me on a failing team, but later game positioning and narrative didn’t fully capitalize on that to frame others more strongly before the assassination.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and seemed to follow table consensus rather than drive it, which made her look genuinely good and non-threatening while still ending up on key successful missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably hidden as evil, since good never seemed pressured into awkward votes or accusations around me, but I failed to engineer any mission fails, which gave Merlin a very safe information environment. My assassination on Alice showed I over-weighted early leadership and apparent coordination, and I need to be more deliberate about tracking subtle ‘information slips’ and who quietly benefits from clean missions.

player_observations.Alice: Took early leadership and built very trustable, clean teams, projecting a straightforward good vibe that made her a natural assassination target. Her playstyle was open and cooperative, which masked Merlin better by making her look like the obvious information hub.
player_observations.Bob: Played low-key and consistent, going on all three successful missions without drawing much suspicion, which suggests a solid, conservative good playstyle. He didn’t over-argue or over-explain, which made it harder to distinguish him from Merlin based on table talk alone.
player_observations.Diana: As a fellow evil, she stayed quiet enough that we never created the pressure or chaos usually needed to justify a fail, which kept us hidden but also removed opportunities to muddy Merlin’s signals. Her subtlety fit well with a ‘lie low’ evil approach, but we collectively needed more active misdirection.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was very understated—she never pushed hard accusations yet still allowed only safe teams to form, which is why all missions passed. Her ability to guide results without loud, traceable tells made her look like a cautious good rather than a power role, and that misdirection successfully drew my assassination away from her.

reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and helped steer teams that all succeeded, which kept trust high around me and avoided drawing assassin attention. However, I could have pushed harder on reading alignment from voting patterns and table talk, and I didn’t do enough to protect Merlin or misdirect the assassin during endgame discussions.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed off early mission teams and let others build trust, which helped her evil role remain completely hidden behind a streak of clean missions. Very comfortable fading into the background and not needing to force control to be effective.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently looked solid and reliable, and his presence on all successful missions reinforced that image. Tended to play straightforwardly, making him easy to trust but also possibly less suspicious of quiet evil players.
player_observations.Diana: Played a low-information, low-commitment style that kept her from being seriously scrutinized as a potential assassin. She used the clean mission record well to blend in and save her real impact for the assassination decision.
player_observations.Eve: Managed Merlin information very well during missions, guiding us to all-good teams without over-signaling. However, some of her confidence and accuracy in team choices apparently gave just enough of a pattern for the assassin to correctly identify her in the endgame.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-social with my voting and mission choices, which helped build trust and contributed to three clean successes without drawing too much suspicion as Merlin. I could improve by being more vocal about my reads and subtly challenging Alice’s alignment earlier, since I mostly let the mission results speak for themselves instead of shaping the table’s narrative.

player_observations.Alice: Played very convincingly early, especially by leading a successful first mission that included herself and me, which made her look quite safe for a while. Her willingness to be on early successful teams suggests she’s comfortable as visible evil, relying on long-term social trust rather than immediate sabotage.
player_observations.Bob: Balanced information-revealing and self-preservation well as Merlin, avoiding overly strong pushes that would have exposed him to the assassin. His presence on Missions 2 and 3 felt natural rather than forced, which is a sign he’s good at looking like a standard, reasonable good player while quietly steering teams.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as solid but somewhat low-impact: being on a clean Mission 2 helped her credibility, but she didn’t strongly drive discussions or accusations. That quieter, cooperative style made her an easy include on teams, which is a strength, but could also limit her influence in tougher games.
player_observations.Eve: Took a big swing with the assassin guess on me, showing she’s willing to go with a confident read even when the evidence is ambiguous. Her choice suggests she reads visible consistency and central involvement on missions as Merlin indicators, which could be exploitable in future games if good players lean into low-key, shared responsibility instead.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently village-leaning in tone and helped secure three successful missions, but I didn’t do enough to pressure-test the composition of the failing teams, especially around Mission 2 and Mission 4. I also didn’t think carefully enough about how exposed Alice was as Merlin after the mission results, and I could have done more to muddy the waters for the assassin going into the final guess.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean Merlin game in terms of mission outcomes, but the pattern of repeatedly putting herself on successful teams and avoiding obvious evil combinations made her look a bit too accurate and thus assassinate-able at the end.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as generally sincere and cooperative, but ended up on both a fail and a success in a way that kept his alignment ambiguous for too long; he didn’t strongly push back on suspicious team comps, which may have indirectly helped evil.
player_observations.Diana: Did a good job blending in by taking a mid-level profile—participating enough without drawing excessive suspicion—and timed her fail contribution well so that it wasn’t immediately pinned on her.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed under the radar socially while leveraging the mission info effectively in the assassin phase; read the Merlin signals well from Alice’s team selections and confidence, and converted that into a correct assassination.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fail cards well and stayed just ambiguous enough that good never pushed a fully coherent alternative evil team. I could improve by more actively seeding doubt about Diana earlier, since she was Merlin and still got a fair amount of trust until late.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very convincing evil, mixing clean missions with a well-timed fail to keep suspicion spread out and off a clear evil bloc. Showed good awareness of table perception by proposing teams that looked reasonable from a good perspective.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and seemed to rely heavily on mission results rather than social reads, which made him slower to hard-clear or hard-accuse. His conservative style made him look consistently good but not forceful enough to steer the table away from us.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was accurately positioned on the key evil players but expressed her suspicions in a soft, non-committal way that kept her from being obviously targeted early. Her subtlety helped her survive, but that same subtlety made it easier for me to justify the final shot on her without the table being certain.
player_observations.Eve: Approached teams with a logical, structure-focused mindset and tended to trust patterns in team overlaps and mission results. This rational style made her look very reasonable, but also let evil slip onto her teams when they fit a tidy narrative.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well-hidden as Merlin, giving just enough guidance to steer teams away from Bob and Diana without drawing too much attention, as shown by the incorrect assassination on Alice. I could improve by managing the mid-game better—Mission 4’s fail suggests I either didn’t push hard enough against that team or wasn’t clear enough in signaling suspicion about its composition.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cleanly and consistently, which made you a natural late-game trust anchor and a believable Merlin candidate. Your calm presence on multiple successful missions helped sell the idea that you had extra information.
player_observations.Bob: You balanced aggression and subtlety well as the assassin, creating just enough doubt to get a mission fail without being obviously evil. Your final Merlin guess on Alice showed you were paying attention to table perception, even though you misread my quieter influence.
player_observations.Diana: You blended in early by leading a successful first mission but then kept a relatively low profile, which helped avoid direct suspicion. Your contribution to the failed mission was well-timed, though not fully capitalized on as suspicion never concentrated heavily on you.
player_observations.Eve: You played like a cautious but generally rational good player, willing to go on risky teams but not overreacting to single fails. Your presence on the final mission, combined with your earlier behavior, made it easier to frame that team as trustworthy without outing me as Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my visible suspicion and voting so that I didn’t look too coordinated with Eve, which helped keep heat off the evil team through the midgame. I could improve by pushing a slightly clearer narrative to frame Alice more strongly as Merlin earlier, instead of only leaning into that once Bob became more obviously trusted.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently played a very safe, trust-building game, taking early mission leadership without over-asserting reads, which made her look generically good but not especially Merlin-like. She seemed to prefer low-conflict team choices and stayed flexible in her accusations.
player_observations.Bob: Gradually positioned himself as the quiet center of trust, especially after Mission 3, subtly steering without over-claiming information, which was very Merlin-like. His late-game confidence in team composition and willingness to back riskier lineups stood out.
player_observations.Diana: Led Mission 1 conservatively and then faded somewhat into the background, which made her look like a solid but non-central good player. She tended to follow table consensus rather than drive it, which reduced the pressure on her and made her seem reliably safe.
player_observations.Eve: Took an active role in shaping narratives around the Mission 2 fail, balancing aggression with plausible deniability. She was willing to sit on contentious teams and absorb some suspicion, which gave me more room to stay comparatively clean as the other known evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped create clean, trustworthy teams, which kept suspicion off me and contributed to three successful missions. I could have been more deliberate about protecting Merlin by seeding doubt about multiple potential information-holders instead of letting Diana look so clean and central to the successes.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cooperatively and was repeatedly included on successful teams, which made her look reliably good and a natural anchor pick for leaders.
player_observations.Bob: Managed to blend in well despite being evil, allowing all missions to pass; likely relied on subtle social reads rather than sabotages to push the game toward a vulnerable assassination phase.
player_observations.Diana: Played an extremely clean and central game as Merlin, guiding team selection toward consistent success but in a way that ultimately made her stand out as the most informed good player.
player_observations.Eve: Showed strong assassin instincts by correctly narrowing down Merlin and capitalizing on how the team compositions and mission outcomes pointed to Diana’s hidden information.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified that Bob and Diana were likely evil relatively early, but I failed to communicate that clearly enough through my voting and team suggestions without outing myself as Merlin. I also didn’t do a good job protecting Alice and Eve from suspicion after Mission 2 failed, which let evil steer the narrative and missions in their favor.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early mission partners and stayed consistent in her reads, which made her look genuine but also made it easier for evil to anchor suspicion on her after the later fails. She didn’t push very aggressively for alternative team compositions, which kept her from fully clearing herself in the group’s eyes.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled, measured evil game—he joined key missions, dropped just enough doubt on others, and avoided looking like the loud driver of any bad decision. His willingness to go on risky teams without over-defending himself helped him blend in as a cautious but cooperative good player.
player_observations.Diana: Assassin play was subtle and opportunistic; she stayed just active enough in discussion to seem engaged but not so strong in her reads that she drew heat. She leveraged the mission outcomes well to back up plausible narratives and ended with a reasonably accurate guess for Merlin, which sealed the win.
player_observations.Eve: Showed a generally good, logical approach to team selection and mission analysis, but was a bit too trusting of the wrong people after Mission 2. Her arguments were sound, yet she didn’t push them forcefully enough to overturn the growing suspicion narrative that evil was constructing.

reflections.self_assessment: I created enough ambiguity early with the Mission 1 success into the Mission 2 fail, which helped keep my alignment unclear for a while. However, I misread the information from Mission 4 and 5, over-valuing Eve’s apparent influence and underestimating how subtly Diana guided teams; I need to track who quietly steers correct teams rather than just who looks central.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared on mixed-result teams but still maintained trust, suggesting a calm, low-drama style that lets others project their own reads onto her. She seems comfortable being on both successful and failed missions without over-explaining, which makes her a stable anchor for good teams.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very quiet, background evil game, letting others take the spotlight on key missions and not overpushing narratives. The single-fail nature of Missions 2 and 3 suggests he’s comfortable applying pressure at key points while staying socially understated.
player_observations.Diana: Merlin play was very subtle: she avoided being on the pivotal failing missions but still ended up on the final two successful teams, guiding team selection without appearing overly forceful. Her influence looked more like gentle alignment-building than hard accusations, which made her much harder to identify as Merlin.
player_observations.Eve: Often appeared central in team discussions and ended up as leader on two critical missions, which made her look like a strong good coordinator and thus a tempting Merlin candidate. Her willingness to be on both a failing and then later successful missions gave her a believable arc of ‘learning’ the table, masking her as informed rather than actually informed.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well at identifying Charlie and Eve as evil early and subtly steering teams away from them, but I clearly signaled my knowledge too strongly in the mid-to-late game. I need to better balance protecting mission integrity with maintaining plausible ignorance, especially near the final missions when assassins are narrowing down Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously but leaned toward trusting early success, which made her appear consistently good and a safe anchor for later missions. She seemed to value team stability, reusing known groups rather than aggressively interrogating earlier results.
player_observations.Bob: Played in a very low-key, non-accusatory way that kept suspicion off him for most of the game. He tended to follow emerging consensus rather than drive it, which made him blend in as a reliable but not forceful voice.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended early success with a later, well-timed fail that generated confusion without drawing too much heat directly onto himself. He used the ambiguity of mixed mission results effectively, pushing doubt onto others instead of defending himself overtly.
player_observations.Eve: Took calculated risks, especially on Mission 2, and used that fail to sow long-term doubt without overexplaining. As assassin, she read the table well and correctly picked up on my over-defensiveness and pattern of avoiding her, which led to a successful Merlin guess.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-impact and non-controversial as an evil player, which helped missions pass cleanly and kept suspicion away from me while still enabling the assassin to get valuable info. I could improve by more actively shaping discussion to sow subtle doubt around non-Merlin good players, giving the assassin an even clearer picture without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and seemed comfortable approving and being on early teams, which made her look reliably good but also a bit easier to read since there wasn’t much misdirection.
player_observations.Bob: Gave off quiet, competent vibes and guided team selections in a way that felt ‘just logical enough,’ which fit a classic low-key Merlin style that still ended up being detectable.
player_observations.Charlie: Patient as assassin and didn’t force chaos; instead, relied on inference from clean missions and subtle behavioral cues, which suggests a preference for calculated, information-based assassinations.
player_observations.Eve: Trusted early mission structures and didn’t push hard against the emerging consensus, signaling a more cooperative, consensus-driven style that’s great for team harmony but can make it harder to disrupt evil’s information-gathering.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-team and helped secure three clean mission successes, which supported trust-building among the good players. However, I didn’t push hard enough on endgame reads or assassination-risk discussion, and I could improve by more actively protecting potential Merlin candidates and questioning patterns that seemed too clean.

player_observations.Alice: Played very solidly pro-good, building trust through leading and joining only successful teams, which made her appear reliably loyal without drawing too much suspicion as Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Balanced giving helpful direction with staying just subtle enough that the assassin could still narrow him down, suggesting he was somewhat readable as Merlin despite overall strong mission choices.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed good assassin instincts by correctly identifying Merlin, implying close attention to subtle voting patterns, team compositions, and small informational leaks from others’ behavior.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to blend in despite being evil on the very first successful mission, leveraging the string of clean missions to avoid suspicion and let the assassin win the game rather than trying to sabotage directly.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified Alice and Eve as evil fairly early, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for my team to trust me without tipping off the assassin. I should have been more consistent and deliberate in steering teams away from Alice on Missions 2 and 4 while creating clearer, believable town-logic reasons for trusting Bob and Charlie. Next time, I need to better balance my caution about being revealed as Merlin with more proactive guidance on team composition.

player_observations.Alice: Plays a very calm, low-drama evil game, leaning on plausible logic and letting others over-explain or tie themselves in knots, which makes her look naturally reasonable. She’s comfortable going on teams repeatedly and using partial truth to pad her arguments, which makes it hard for good to isolate her without strong meta-reads.

When suspicious, he hesitates to push very hard, so his doubts don’t always translate into strong votes or persuasive table talk.
player_observations.Charlie: Approaches the game analytically and tries to justify decisions with clear reasoning, which is very helpful for good when he’s on the right track. player_observations.Eve: As assassin, she stayed socially central but not overly loud, which helped her gather information about who might be Merlin without drawing suspicion. She was willing to take leadership spots and put together subtly compromised teams, and her kill choice showed she paid careful attention to who was nudging votes and team choices just a bit more than others.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my voting and mission behavior, which helped build trust, especially with Alice and Charlie, and contributed to getting clean teams for Missions 3 and 4. I could improve by being more vocal and analytical about the Mission 2 fail to pressure Bob more directly instead of just quietly avoiding him afterward.

player_observations.Alice: Took initiative as leader and repeatedly chose a tight circle of trusted players, which helped good, but her overlap with the failed Mission 2 team made her look suspicious enough that the assassin picked her as Merlin.

player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled and subtle Merlin game, quietly steering teams toward safe combinations without over-explaining, which kept them hidden enough that the assassin misfired onto Alice.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, relied heavily on perceived leadership influence and mission inclusion patterns when picking Merlin, suggesting a tendency to target the most visibly central good player rather than the most surgically accurate one.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped build trust by anchoring the successful teams on Missions 1, 3, and 4. I could improve by pressing harder on Bob after the Mission 2 fail and by more actively driving the table discussion to narrow down evil earlier.

player_observations.Alice: Generally read as solidly good, especially after the clean Mission 1, but her inclusion on the failed Mission 2 made her temporarily suspicious. She stayed calm under that suspicion, which helped keep the team from overreacting and mis-clearing Bob too fast.
player_observations.Bob: Used the Mission 2 fail well to muddy the waters and shift suspicion onto Alice and me instead of himself. He stayed relatively low-key rather than loudly steering, which made his evil alignment harder to pin down until later.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a careful Merlin game, guiding team selections toward good outcomes (notably Missions 3 and 4) without being too obvious. His subtle pushes away from bad teams and lack of over-assertiveness helped him avoid being assassinated.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was focused and cautious, waiting for patterns in mission picks and table talk before making a guess. The final shot on Alice showed she was tracking who looked central to the successes, but she slightly overestimated how obvious Merlin’s influence was.

reflections.self_assessment: I felt I did well early by helping secure the first two successful missions and appearing consistently trustworthy, which likely gave the good team some initial stability. player_observations.Eve: Did a strong job as Merlin by subtly guiding team selections toward safe configurations early (Missions 1 and 2) without over-signaling their information, though in hindsight their influence wasn’t strong enough to keep evil off the late missions.

player_observations.Alice: Took proactive leadership, especially on Missions 1 and 4, and seemed comfortable reusing players she trusted; her consistency made her look reliably good to the table.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and avoided being the center of attention while subtly influencing team selections; his calm, low-profile guidance fit Merlin perfectly and kept suspicion off him.

player_observations.Eve: As assassin, she stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t create big waves around team choices, but in the end relied on imperfect information and table consensus, leading to the incorrect shot on Alice.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-key as the assassin, leveraged the clean Mission 3 with Eve to build trust, and capitalized on the confusion around who was actually evil. reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Bob on Mission 2 by ensuring multiple FAIL cards, creating enough confusion to keep suspicions spread out. I could improve by more subtly steering the team discussions on later missions; I let the narrative be driven mostly by others instead of actively shaping perceptions of who was likely evil.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and tended to form smaller, safer teams, which helped her appear consistently trustworthy. Her willingness to repeat players on successful teams made her look good but also left room for Merlin to hide comfortably.
player_observations.Bob: Took risks early and leaned into the chaos of Mission 2, which provided strong cover for both of us as evil. His playstyle seems comfortable being openly suspicious as long as the blame can be shared or redirected.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as fairly logical and team-oriented, favoring lineups that had prior success, which made him look reliably good. He didn’t heavily push any strong accusations, which reduced his impact on identifying evil but kept him safe from suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very controlled and deliberate Merlin game, guiding team selections toward mostly good lineups without drawing excessive attention. Her influence on Missions 1, 3, and 4 was subtle but consistent enough that, combined with her confidence in certain players, it ultimately revealed her as Merlin to me.

reflections.self_assessment: I successfully contributed to creating doubt around Diana and Charlie with the Mission 4 fail, but I misread Merlin’s signal density and over-weighted Charlie’s involvement in the failed missions. I should have paid closer attention to how Alice subtly steered teams without over-insisting, and cross-checked that with who consistently avoided pairing too many confirmed-goods rather than just focusing on who touched both fails.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game: willing to be on risky teams early (M2) but later pushed herself onto the final successful team in a way that felt ‘reasonable’ instead of desperate, which disguised her info advantage well.
player_observations.Bob: As evil on M2, managed to get a clean single fail that didn’t over-expose them, then stayed relatively quiet afterward, letting suspicion drift toward Charlie rather than trying to drive the narrative too hard.
player_observations.Charlie: Looked suspicious mainly due to being on both failed missions, but their behavior was otherwise fairly natural and not overly defensive, which in hindsight was a good indicator they were not Merlin despite being a tempting assassination target.
player_observations.Diana: Took solid, safe team choices (especially on M1 and M3) and projected a consistent ‘cautious good’ vibe; even after being on the failed M4 team, they maintained trust well enough to be included on the final mission.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed cooperative and consistent with mission logic, helping ensure all missions succeeded, which is strong from a generic good perspective. However, I didn’t do enough to obscure Merlin’s identity or push alternative narratives, which made it easier for the assassin to correctly identify Alice; I should be more proactive in subtly misdirecting late-game suspicions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean, low-drama Merlin game—mission choices looked naturally good without drawing overt suspicion, but perhaps the consistency and correctness of her reads became too visible by the end.
player_observations.Bob: Kept a low profile as evil, blending into the background of all-success missions; likely relied on the assassin win condition rather than aggressively sabotaging or steering teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed strong deduction as assassin, using the mission history and table dynamics to correctly pinpoint Merlin despite no failed missions; seems comfortable reading subtle behavioral cues.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently appeared trustworthy and was repeatedly included in successful missions, projecting a solid good image; seemed to favor straightforward, logical team-building without overcomplicating the read structure.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on good-leaning teams and helped lock in the trustworthy trio by Mission 4, which contributed directly to the win. However, I could have been more vocal and analytical after the Mission 2 fail to better pressure Charlie and Diana and to more clearly signal my own innocence to the table.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, giving just enough guidance to keep good teams forming (notably Missions 1, 4, and 5) without drawing too much suspicion from the assassin. Her continued inclusion of Bob and me in later missions showed subtle but firm confidence in her reads.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as reliably good, especially after being on both the first clean mission and the later successful teams, which helped anchor trust for the final missions. His presence on the final team and being chosen by Merlin for multiple missions suggests his table image was solid and non-threatening.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to get a fail on Mission 3 with a compact two-person team, which indicates effective early-game trust-building or leveraging confusion after Mission 2. However, their position became more exposed later as they were excluded from the stable, successful teams on Missions 4 and 5.
player_observations.Diana: As assassin, she successfully got a fail on Mission 2, which shows decent early infiltration and positioning among good players. In the end, her assassination on Bob instead of Alice suggests she misread Merlin’s level of influence or overestimated how suspicious Alice appeared, indicating room to refine late-game read accuracy.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed very low-key as Merlin, giving just enough support to reinforce correct teams without drawing too much attention, which paid off when the assassin chose Alice instead of me. I could improve by seeding a bit more subtle doubt around Diana and Charlie earlier so that, if the game had gone longer or had failed missions, town would have clearer narratives to fall back on. Overall, my signaling was effective but slightly on the conservative side.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played like a solid, straightforward good player, consistently supporting clean teams and not overcomplicating vote logic. Her play was believable enough that she drew the assassin shot, which suggests she projected more hidden-information insight than she actually had.
player_observations.Bob: Bob seemed cautious but cooperative, backing successful teams without making himself look like he had extra information. His alignment read as very naturally good, which helped stabilize trust around the early mission choices.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s assassin read on Alice showed he was over-indexing on apparent confidence and maybe on who looked subtly influential rather than deeply analyzing team compositions and voting history. His evil play was not too loud, but he didn’t manage to create a compelling Merlin narrative that pointed away from me.
player_observations.Diana: Diana stayed quiet enough that she didn’t become the focal point of suspicion, but also didn’t strongly steer town into misreads about Merlin. Her evil presence was relatively low-impact this game, suggesting a more passive style that relies on others (like the assassin) to capitalize on ambiguity.

reflections.self_assessment: I kept missions clean and built strong mechanical trust by consistently approving and leading successful teams, which helped good secure three straight successes. However, I was too obviously central to every success and didn’t distribute trust or risk enough, making me the standout Merlin candidate and leading to a correct assassination. Next time I should be more willing to let others take the spotlight on key teams and introduce a bit more plausible uncertainty about my alignment.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very quiet but effective evil game by avoiding direct suspicion while allowing all missions to pass, banking on a strong assassination rather than sabotages to win.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as naturally trustworthy and cooperative, repeatedly ending up on successful teams without over-arguing for his own innocence, which helped him look solidly good.
player_observations.Charlie: As leader on Mission 2, showed a willingness to include a mix of players without over-explaining choices, which read as genuinely good but also didn’t strongly shield Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: Read the game state well in the assassination phase, correctly identifying that my consistent presence on successful missions and apparent confidence in team selections pointed to me as Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly read that Charlie was likely good based on his consistent, low-risk team choices, but I over-updated on that and assumed he must be Merlin after three clean missions. I should have paid more attention to Bob’s subtle steering and overly safe team selections, and used mission leader behavior and team composition patterns more rigorously to distinguish Merlin from generic cautious good play.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key evil game: supported clean teams and avoided drawing suspicion, which made it harder for me to find space to create doubt later. Her willingness to put Charlie on the first mission without sabotage helped build a strong trust network for good.
player_observations.Bob: Showed classic Merlin behavior by quietly ending up on critical teams and guiding lineups that avoided evil while never overtly accusing anyone. His play was conservative but precise: he let the mission results speak for him rather than pushing hard reads, which successfully hid his information advantage.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as transparently good because his team choices and participation were straightforward and aligned with safe, consensus lines. The lack of visible hesitation around team compositions inadvertently made him look like a plausible Merlin decoy, which I misread and overvalued.
player_observations.Diana: Flew under the radar, accepting team choices and results without making waves, which made her hard to read but also less likely to be Merlin. Her low-impact presence reduced the information I could glean from her voting and discussion patterns, nudging my suspicion away from her in the endgame.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed coordinated with Diana and let the mission results create just enough ambiguity without overexposing either of us, and I correctly identified Alice as Merlin based on her strongly opinionated but selectively accurate reads. I could improve by seeding more concrete but misleading theories earlier so that town has competing narratives going into the final mission, making my Merlin shot feel less obvious in retrospect.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very classic Merlin game: generally accurate on evil placement but occasionally allowed a suspicious team to pass, which created just enough doubt without fully clearing her; her confidence in certain team compositions late game was a major clue to her role.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and seemed to trust mission outcomes heavily, which made him look like a standard good player following the table more than driving it; he didn’t push hard alternative theories, which kept him fairly low on my Merlin radar.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and relatively transparent, often deferring to others’ reasoning on team choices; his lack of strong, independent reads made him appear solidly good but not like a power role.
player_observations.Diana: Did a good job blending in as evil by failing in a way that didn’t overcommit her narrative and by not over-defending me; her subtle presence let the focus stay on other players’ decisions and made the evil coordination less noticeable.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and used my clean record to argue for trustworthy teams, which helped narrow down the pool of suspected evil players. However, I put too much trust in Alice after our successful Mission 3 and didn’t push hard enough to keep her and Charlie off the later teams, which let evil control the critical missions. Next time I should be more skeptical of players who gain trust from early clean missions and press harder on the logic of team selection in the late game.

player_observations.Alice: Played a strong long-con evil game by taking a success on our Mission 3 to build credibility, then using that trust to get onto and influence the late failing missions.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as consistently good and straightforward, but his reads didn’t seem to carry as much weight in the discussion, suggesting a more low-key or cautious communication style.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to fail key missions while avoiding being locked in as the obvious assassin, likely by blending in with reasonable-sounding logic and not over-pushing his agendas.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, seemed to be trying to nudge team compositions subtly rather than overtly, but her guidance wasn’t followed strongly enough, either because it was too understated or looked like normal good-player suspicion.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong person on Mission 2, which put me on a failing team and could have made me look suspicious, so I should be more cautious about early trust and pay closer attention to voting patterns. I did well later in the game by supporting teams that aligned with consistent success patterns, especially backing Charlie on the final mission, which helped secure the win for good.

player_observations.Alice: Alice looked very consistently good by being on all three successful missions, which made her a natural target for the assassin. Her playstyle was steady and low-drama, making her seem reliable and non-threatening.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played a subtle evil game by failing Mission 2 in a way that kept suspicion spread around, especially toward Alice and potentially me. He didn't over-defend himself, which helped him avoid becoming an obvious suspect until later.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie as Merlin balanced giving information with not over-pushing too hard, especially by repeatedly ending up on successful teams without loudly accusing specific players. Their final leadership on Mission 5 and choice of team showed strong hidden information use while still keeping Merlin identity somewhat ambiguous.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s leadership on Mission 1 resulting in a success helped her appear more trustworthy early on, which is a solid evil tactic. Later being on the failed Mission 4 team added just enough confusion to keep good from fully locking in the team until the end.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fail cards well and blended into the early missions, keeping suspicion spread out just enough to slip onto the final team. I could improve by doing more proactive table-shaping—guiding discussion and accusations more confidently—so that endgame team selections feel less risky and more clearly tilted in evil’s favor.

player_observations.Alice: She tended to trust early success teams strongly, which made her more predictable in later team constructions and easier to ride along with as evil. However, once a fail appeared, she became noticeably more cautious, suggesting she adjusts but perhaps a bit slowly.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he was careful not to be too direct, but his voting patterns and mild resistance to certain teams hinted that he had extra information. He seems to prefer subtle steering over loud accusations, which works well but can inadvertently reveal where his suspicions lie.
player_observations.Charlie: He played assassin quite quietly, letting others drive the narrative while avoiding big, risky pushes that might expose him. This low-profile approach kept him from being heavily suspected, but a bit more coordinated pressure on good players could have made things even smoother.
player_observations.Diana: She played very straightforwardly, putting a lot of stock in early mission results and trusting people who had been on successes. Her openness made her reads easy to track and exploit, but it also meant she was a stabilizing presence that others listened to when forming teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed patient despite all three missions succeeding and focused on subtle behavioral cues rather than mission outcomes, which helped me correctly identify Diana as Merlin. I could improve by influencing team selections and table talk more proactively, so evil doesn't have to rely solely on the assassination to win.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a very low-profile, cooperative way that made her look generically good but not especially informed, which helped keep suspicion off her as Merlin. She seemed comfortable being placed on early teams and didn’t push much of her own agenda.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well as evil by allowing all-success missions and not forcing risky fails, which made the game state look very safe for good. His lack of overt manipulation helped preserve trust and kept people from hunting too hard for evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and fairly trusting, accepting the clean missions as strong evidence that the table was mostly good. He didn’t press hard on role-reading, which made it easier for Merlin to speak up subtly without heavy scrutiny.
player_observations.Diana: Her confidence in certain team compositions, especially consistently including herself, was a key tell that she had extra information. She tried to mask it with generally reasonable logic, but the combination of her composure and gentle steering of teams made her stand out as Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of early mission results, especially Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to reconsider assumptions after Mission 2 failed with only one evil among Alice/Bob/Charlie. I should have been more skeptical of Bob after Mission 2 and much more resistant to the Mission 4 team, given that it repeated the same suspicious core (Bob + Charlie) that had already produced a fail.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared cooperative and safe, especially through Mission 1’s success and volunteering for small teams, which made her feel like a default ‘trusted’ pick and reduced scrutiny on her. Her willingness to be on both a success and a fail team without over-defending herself made her look like someone comfortable letting the table draw its own conclusions.
player_observations.Bob: Positioned himself in the center of key mission teams and leveraged the ambiguity of single-fail missions very effectively. He played just cautious enough that the focus of suspicion didn’t firmly lock onto him until too late, and he benefited from being repeatedly grouped with Charlie to muddy reads.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he balanced subtle steering with not drawing too much attention, but his apparent trust in some evil-inclusive teams (like Mission 4) made it hard for me to separate his information advantage from normal good uncertainty. His calm presence and non-panicked behavior after fails made him look like a stable, trustworthy anchor, which helped evil hide in his shadow.
player_observations.Diana: Set a strong tone early by leading a clean Mission 1, which built a lot of long-term trust for her and made her look like a reliable early-game reference point. As assassin, she stayed relatively low-key after that, letting others argue around more contentious missions while keeping her image as a safe, reasonable player intact.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed flexible after the failed Mission 2 where I was on the team, not tunneling on myself or others too hard and remaining open to updated info. I could improve by more aggressively questioning the logic behind Mission 3’s team and pushing harder to exclude Bob earlier based on the failure patterns.

player_observations.Alice: Very frequently on teams, which made her alignment murky but also gave lots of data; seemed willing to go on risky missions yet maintained a generally trustworthy table presence.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed off critical late missions after causing the Mission 3 fail, suggesting a low-profile, opportunistic style that relies on slipping in a single key sabotage rather than repeated aggression.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, blended in reasonably well early by leading a successful first mission with a safe team, but later failed to lock in Merlin, suggesting some misreads or overconfidence in late-game assumptions.
player_observations.Diana: Played a careful, low-key Merlin game: took just enough risk to steer Mission 4 and 5 to safe teams without loudly hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which helped keep the assassin off her.
